key.name: communication-method
key.description:
The method used by speech-dispatcher to communicate with it's clients. unix_socket -- communication over Unix sockets represented by a file in the filesystem (see SocketPath below). This method works only locally, but is prefered for standard session setup, where every user runs his own instance of Speech Dispatcher to get voice feedback on his own computer.
inet_socket -- alternatively, you can start Speech Dispatcher on a TCP port and connect to it via hostname/port. This allows for a more flexible setup, where you can use Speech Dispatcher over network from different machines. See also the Port and LocalhostAccessOnly configuration variables.

key.name: socket-path
key.summary: Path for unix socket to use or 'default'
key.description: Socket Path is either "default" or a full path to the filesystem where the driving Unix socket file should be created in case the CommunicationMethod is set to "unix_socket". The default is $XDG_RUNTIME_DIR/speech-dispatcher/speechd.sock where $XDG_RUNTIME_DIR is the directory specified by the XDG Base Directory Specification. Do not change this unless you have a reason and know what you are doing.

key.name: port
key.description: The Port on which Speech Dispatcher should be available to clients if the "inet_socket" communication method is used.

key.name: localhost-access-only
key.description: By default, if "inet_socket" communication method is used, the specified port is opened only for connections coming from localhost. If localhost-access-only set to false it disables this access control. It means that the port will be accessible from all computers on the network. If you turn off this option, please make sure you set up some system rules on what computers are and are not allowed to access the Speech Dispatcher port.

key.name: timeout
key.description: By default, Speech Dispatcher is configured to shut itself down after a period of time if no clients are connected. The timeout value is in seconds, and is started when the last client disconnects. A value of 0 disables the timeout.

key.name: log-level
key.description: The Log Level is a number between 0 and 5 specifying the verbosity of information to the logfile or screen 0 means nothing, 5 means everything (not recommended).

key.name: log-dir
key.description: The Log Dir specifies where the Speech Dispatcher logs reside Specify "stdout" for standard console output or a custom log directory path. 'default' means the logs are written to the default destination (e.g. a preconfigured system directory or the home directory if .speech-dispatcher is present) DO NOT COMMENT OUT THIS OPTION, leave as "default" for standard logging

key.name: custom-log-file
key.description: The Custom Log File allows logging all messages # regardless of priority, to the given destination.

key.name: default-rate
key.description: The Default Rate controls how fast the synthesizer is going to speak. The value must be between -100 (slowest) and +100 (fastest), default is 0.

key.name: default-pitch
key.description: The Default Pitch controls the pitch of the synthesized voice. The value must be between -100 (lowest) and +100 (highest), default is 0.

key.name: default-pitch-range
key.description: The Default Pitch Range controls the pitch range of the synthesized voice. The value must be between -100 (lowest) and +100 (highest), default is 0.

key.name: default-volume
key.description: The Default Volume controls the default volume of the voice. It is a value between -100 (softly) and +100 (loudly). Currently, +100 maps to the default volume of the synthesizer.

key.name: default-voice-type
key.description: The Default Voice Type controls which voice type should be used by default. Voice types are symbolic names which map to particular voices provided by the synthesizer according to the output module configuration. Please see the synthesizer-specific configuration in etc/speech-dispatcher/modules/ to see which voices are assigned to different symbolic names. The following symbolic names are currently supported: MALE1, MALE2, MALE3, FEMALE1, FEMALE2, FEMALE3, CHILD_MALE, CHILD_FEMALE

key.name: default-language
key.description: The Default language with which to speak

key.name: default-client-name
key.description: The Default Client Name specifies the name of a client who didn't introduce himself at the beginning of an SSIP session.

key.name: default-priority
key.description: The Default Priority. Use with caution, normally this shouldn't be changed globally (at this place)

key.name: default-pause-context
key.description: The Default Pause Context specifies by how many index marks a speech cursor should return when resuming after a pause. This is roughly equivalent to the number of sentences before the place of the execution of pause that will be repeated.

key.name: default-punctuation-mode
key.description: The Default Punctuation Mode sets the way dots, commas, exclamation marks, question marks etc. are interpreted. none: they are ignored some: some of them are sent to synthesis (see DefaultPunctuationSome) all: all punctuation marks are sent to synthesis

key.name: default-capital-letter-recognition
key.description: The Default Capital Letter Recognition: if set to "spell", capital letters should be spelled (e.g. "capital b"), if set to "icon", capital letters are indicated by inserting a special sound before them but they should be read normally, it set to "none" capital letters are not recognized (by default)

key.name: default-spelling
key.description: The Default Spelling: if set to true, all messages will be spelled unless set otherwise (this is usually not something you want to do.)

key.name: audio-output-method
key.description: Chooses between the possible sound output systems: "pulse" - PulseAudio "alsa" - Advanced Linux Sound System "oss" - Open Sound System "nas" - Network Audio System "libao" - A cross platform audio library Pulse audio is the default and recommended sound server. OSS and ALSA are only provided for compatibility with architectures that do not include Pulse Audio. NAS provides network transparency, but is not very well tested. libao is a cross platform library with plugins for different sound systems and provides alternative output for Pulse Audio and ALSA as well as for other backends.

key.name: audio-pulse-server
key.description: Pulse audio server name or "default" for the default pulse server

key.name: audio-pulse-min-length
key.description: Minimum length of pulse audio packets.

key.name: audio-alsa-device
key.description: Audio device for ALSA output

key.name: audio-oss-device
key.description: Audio device for OSS output

key.name: audio-nas-server
key.description: Route to the Network Audio System server when NAS is chosen for the audio output. Note that NAS server doesn't need to run on your machine, you can use it also over network (for instance when working on remote machines).

key.name: enabled-modules
key.description: This is the list of all output modules that should be enabled. Each is a string separated by colons of the name:module-binary:config-file such as 'espeak:sd_espeak:espeak.conf' and 'swift-generic:sd_generic:swift-generic.conf'

key.name: default-module
key.description: The Default Module selects which output module is the default. You must use one of the names of the modules from the enabled-modules setting.

key.name: language-default-module
key.description: The Language Default Module selects which output modules are prefered for specified languages.
